channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Dismay Grows in Zimbabwe as Underdog Party Tastes Good Life
item.description: As long-awaited elections approach, faith slips in Morgan Tsvangirai’s Movement for Democratic Change.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:credit: Pete Muller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zimbabweans headed to work and school in Harare. Voters are increasingly questioning the country’s erstwhile opposition group.

item.title: Park Geun-hye, Steely Leader of South Korea, Is Battle-Ready
item.description: As the crisis with North Korea escalates, critics and supporters alike wonder if Park Geun-hye may have gone too far in presenting herself as an ultra-tough leader.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Park Geun-hye waved to crowds after her inauguration in Seoul in February, becoming the country’s first female president.

item.title: U.S. Puts Japan in Talks for Pacific Trade Deal
item.description: The possibility of including Japan in the regional agreement gave the deal heft, but it also brought complaints from carmakers in the United States.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Bomb North Korea, Before It’s Too Late
item.description: North Korea’s Musudan missile threatens the security of America and its allies. President Obama should order a narrow, defensive strike before it’s launched.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JEREMI SURI

item.title: Contrasting Views on North Korea Underscore Sensitivities and Lack of Evidence
item.description: A sudden round of finger-pointing highlighted the sensitivity surrounding intelligence estimates in the wake of failures leading up to the Iraq war, and some subsequent missteps involving North Korea.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: U.S. Sanctions on Russians Accused of Rights Violations
item.description: The Obama administration imposed sanctions on about two dozen Russians under a new law that has soured ties with Moscow, but avoided targeting many high-level government figures.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: China Must Exploit Its Shale Gas
item.description: Exploiting China’s vast resources of shale gas is the only short-term way for the country to avoid huge increases in greenhouse gas emissions from burning coal.
item.dc:creator: By ELIZABETH MULLER

item.title: Château Latour Breaks With a Bordeaux Tradition
item.description: Château Latour is stirring tensions with a decision to stop selling its wines through middlemen in an attempt to hold more profit for itself.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC PFANNER
item.media:description: About 6,000 wine merchants gathered in Bordeaux this week to taste the 2012 vintage.

item.title: Syrian Rebels Break With Group Over Qaeda Wing Alliance
item.description: A coalition of insurgents criticized a more radical group’s announced alliance with Al Qaeda’s Iraq branch as a mistake that would benefit only their enemy, President Bashar al-Assad.
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A fighter from Islamist Syrian rebel group the Nusra Front last month in Raqqa Province. Nusra has announced that it is now allied with Al Qaeda’s Iraq branch.

item.title: Albany Teacher Gives Pro-Nazi Writing Assignment
item.description: An unidentified 10th-grade English teacher at Albany High School told students to construct an anti-Semitic argument using historical propaganda.
item.dc:creator: By JESSE McKINLEY

item.title: Morsi Shows Support for Egypt’s Military
item.description: President Mohamed Morsi’s appearance with his top general came amid reports that soldiers had tortured protesters during the 18-day uprising in 2011.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Advisers Urge Changes to Break Stalemate in Italy
item.description: The “wise men” were chosen by President Giorgio Napolitano to help break the stalemate over forming a new governing coaliton.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: The Lede: BBC Won’t Ban ‘Ding Dong! The Witch Is Dead,’ Adopted as Anti-Thatcher Anthem
item.description: The BBC rejected calls to ban the song “Ding Dong! The Witch Is Dead” from its airwaves on Friday, after the apparent success of a Facebook campaign to celebrate the death of Margaret Thatcher by driving it up the British singles chart.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: First Tastes of the 2012 Bordeaux
item.description: This is definitely a vintage to taste before buying. But tasting hundreds of reds in a day? Teeth stained, tongue hurting, you end up resembling a character in a teenage vampire movie, though you feel considerably older.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC PFANNER
item.media:description: Opening week for 2012 wines in the hall of the Bordeaux stock exchange.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Chopper Read, Australia’s Brand Name for Ferocity Is Softened by Illness
item.description: Perhaps the most feared criminal in Melbourne’s criminal history, the man known as Chopper has added another entry in his résumé: cancer patient.
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL
item.media:credit: Katrin Koenning for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Mark Brandon Read, better known as Chopper, with his dog, Bonnie, in Collingwood, a suburb of Melbourne, Australia.

item.title: ArtsBeat: Hopi Masks Sold at Auction After Judge’s Ruling
item.description: The auction in Paris was fiercely contested by the Hopi tribe of northeastern Arizona and generated more than $1 million in sales.
item.dc:creator: By TOM MASHBERG
item.media:description: Bo Lomahquahu, center, with other protesters outside the auction on Friday.

item.title: Rights Groups Question Legality of Targeted Killing
item.description: A nine-page letter sent to President Obama is the most significant critique to date of what has become the centerpiece of the United States’ counterterrorism efforts.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Austria Defends Banking Secrecy Rules
item.description: Austria will not knuckle under to pressure to follow Luxembourg in dropping its banking secrecy rules, the country’s finance minister said.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY and JAMES KANTER

item.title: Taliban Attack Afghan Army Unit
item.description: Insurgents dealt a serious blow to a battalion in eastern Afghanistan on Friday, killing 13 soldiers and overrunning their outpost.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and AZAM AHMED

item.title: Bailout Terms Are Eased for Ireland and Portugal
item.description: Euro zone finance ministers agreed to give Ireland and Portugal more time to repay their bailout loans after a rescue for Cyprus renewed animosity toward the authorities overseeing the single currency area.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Jeroen Dijsselbloem, the president of the so-called Eurogroup of ministers, spoke to members of the media at a meeting of finance ministers in Dublin, Ireland, on Friday.

item.title: WORLD: Chávez’s Lasting Impact
item.description: Even in death, the former leader Hugo Chávez plays an omnipresent role in Venezuela’s presidential campaigns as voters prepare to elect their new leader on Sunday.

item.title: India Ink: In Delhi, Even My Own Car Is No Refuge From Harassment
item.description: Driving in a private vehicle through the streets of Delhi, in broad daylight, is no guarantee that a woman will escape harassment.
item.dc:creator: By PAMPOSH RAINA
item.media:description: A woman driving a car on the outskirts of New Delhi.

item.title: Cameron and Merkel to Discuss British Role in Bloc
item.description: David Cameron of Britain and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany have begun a “not purely routine” weekend visit to discuss Britain’s future in the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 12
item.description: A wholesale fruit market in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Workers sorting mangoes at a wholesale fruit market in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: In the Hytner Era, the National Theater Hit Its Mark
item.description: Starting with “Jerry Springer: The Opera,” Nicholas Hytner has repositioned the three-stage complex as arguably the defining theatrical address in the English-speaking world. And he still has two years to go.
item.dc:creator: By MATT WOLF
item.media:credit: Jonathan Player for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicholas Hytner in 2004, early in his tenure at the National Theater in London.
